thread.title: Royals win with comeback for the ages (or at least since last ye
thread.title_full: Royals win with comeback for the ages (or at least since last ye - KCTV5

author: Neal Jones, News Producer/Editor
title: Royals win with comeback for the ages (or at least since last ye
text:
The Royals dramatic comeback victory over Oakland last year has been a touchstone for KC's fans, players and manager Ned Yost. They all point to that game as the turning point for this franchise. 
They might have a new turning point.
Down 6-2 in the top of the 8th, with Astros fans screaming in anticipation, Kansas City put together an unlikely rally, scoring 5 runs for a 7-6 lead, and ultimately, a 9-6 victory. The governor of Texas even tweeted congratulations to the Astros on advancing to the American League Championship series.
It took good hitting, aggressive base running and some strange hops, but the Royals stunned Houston.
The guys in orange looked a lot like the guys in Oakland green and gold, as a dead and buried Royals team scratched out hit after hit, using a poor defensive play (last year it was a deep ball misplayed by two A's outfielders- this year a ball skipping past Houston shortstop Carlos Correa). In both games. there was a look of disbelief on the Royals opponent's faces.It said, "Hey, we had this! What happened!"
With ace Josh Lester on the mound, KC found a way to rally against Oakland, and they did the same thing against a trio of Astro pitchers in that star-crossed 8th inning.
10 batters came to the plate. The first five men got base hits.
The supreme confidence Houston's players, manager and fans have exhibited all series disappeared. There was  no more celebrating in the Astro dugout. There were no more shots of act pitcher Dallas Keuchel smiling and laughing. In their place: long faces, shocked faces, just like in the Oakland dugout last year.
In both cases, reliever Luke Gregerson played a key role in helping push the Royals ahead.
Who knows where this will lead. Perhaps the Astros will come back and beat the Royals in Game 5 at Kauffman Stadium Wednesday night. Maybe this dramatic rally will do nothing but postpone the Astros celebration.
But, whatever happens, Royals fans have another great memory to savor.
